Oh it's worse than you know. The sheer level of fraud in the fossil trade in china combined with the desperate fumbling of baizuo faggots to defend it has made me re-evaluate a lot of things. I'm also taking a more skeptical look at traditionally accepted animals like Mamenchisaurus and the similar Omeisaurus, which have WAY too long of necks for how short their tails are. This skepticism is also more often being applied to North American and European finds, which I never questioned before. So, I guess congratulations for training me to have a more critical eye. The concept of a "nanny dog" originates from Peter Pan. The story featured a dog called Nana who worked as a nanny. Nana was a Newfoundland dog.

The idea that pitbulls are nanny dogs originates from a 1971 New York Times article with the headline "A Breed That Came Up the Hard Way". A spokesman for a Staffordshire Bull Terrier club was talking about that breed, and she claimed they're known as "nursemaid dogs". This claim was later repeated and distorted until it evolved into its current form.

>system for motivating agents will inevitably recreate the experience of suffering.
Yes. Research into control theory. The solutions life ran into were rediscovered through human rigor to create ideal control systems which are used extensively in our technology. These systems run things like your circulation and breathing, your hormones which regulate growth across your whole body. They use both positive and negative feedback control, and you can't just take the negative away. It would be like making a bicycle which can only turn left. You might naïvely think you could just make three lefts for a right and be fine otherwise, but you can't. The system becomes unstable and you'll be forced to stay in a hard left bank forever, reentering the zero point within it to retain control, and anything right of that point becomes the "new right".

Taking away existing negative feedback creates a fundamentally less stable control system. You will be forced to keep steady positive feedback, and remove some of it to simulate negative feedback. Now you have a worse control system with limited resolution, and anything less than the new zero point of positive feedback just becomes negative feedback with extra steps. Congratulations. If you want a stupid example to better understand, consider the use of opiate drugs. Taking them habitually pushes the needle of positive feedback too far, and the result is a new centering where your natural steady state feels agonizing.

I am not dragging your ass through an entire college level control theory course to absolutely prove what I'm saying is true when you won't even concede to some basic biological facts. I opened with calling your thinking childish because you clearly lack the insight to direct yourself in this topic, and my opinion is unchanged. I would advise you to take what I say as true, and investigate on your own as to why that is. It would be a more productive use of your time than playing 20Q with an asshole on 4chan.

This is one of the better replies I've read on this board, thank you for taking the time to write it. What is your opinion about people with rare mutations of the SCN9A gene who exhibit extremely high pain-tolerance? They apparently aren't the same ones as those patients with congenital analgesia who infamously die young. However, I've had a hard time understanding what would distinguish the two. David Pearce alludes to the mutation as though it were a proof of concept for his "gradients of bliss" idea, and I've read one interview with a patient that seems to support him:
https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2020/01/13/a-world-without-pain
Importantly, she has kids, which goes a long way to undermine the idea that suffering is an evolutionary necessity. However she's not behaviorally anywhere close to a normal person, so it isn't really the case we're discussing. I'd assume you're willing to agree that there's nothing that requires an intelligent organism to suffer in order for it to be successful, but rather, you'd assert that our particular evolutionary history made indispensable use of suffering. Is that right?

In control system terms, I think the best way of understanding the specific idea that Pearce is getting at is a "positive system":
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Positive_systems
Differential rewards exist, but they can only lower you, not cause you to cross the zero point. You might counter by saying this would be experientially the same as suffering. But in my experience at least, I'm familiar with instances of going from "n" to "n-1" without crossing zero, and I can even imagine all of my "negative" experiences working that way. What do you think?

Cephalopods are highly resistant to mutation because they depend on RNA editing for bodily functions. Genetic changes must be much more exact otherwise they're sickly and dying at birth. Nothing else on earth is like this. Cephalopods are not able to withstand "junk mutations" and eventually get something out of them so they barely evolve.

This heavy reliance on RNA editing is a solid argument for intelligent design or intervention existing not for all life on earth, but for some life. In many ways they are clearly intentionally gimped. It's like someone didn't want them developing too early. Brains wrapped around esophagi. Death from mating. It's strange, almost too strange to be arbitrary. It seems that they have put an artificial brake on cephalopod evolution to ensure it only changes when they want to change it, as if they are controlling the timing to guarantee it will become the dominant lifeform. Or more likely - to guarantee it won't. What if current cephalopods are the genetic punishment for a prior civilization's hubris? What if they had to watch their offspring hatch as primitive slugs, knowing they would die out succeeded by mere blobs of organs? What if they had to fade away being told that their progeny was genetically guaranteed to never evolve to their height again and that their lineage was ruined for eternity?

What would it be punishment for? What if the punishers had to cope with a similar event in a great interspecies war and it was revenge? What if they did one worse to the tentacled ones and their ruined progeny at least had evolutionary potential?

>>4370313
I recently had to euthanize my (18 year old, born July 2004) cat because of end stage kidney failure. She was 100% fine and acting normal until the day she had a seizure. Then she was beyond saving within another day and a half. She didn't even have the weight loss/lack of appetite that is common with the disease.
This can be kidney disease or hyperthyroidism (sometimes both, they often go hand in hand). If their kidneys aren't working well they feel nauseous from toxins building up in their system and avoid eating and sometimes vomit after eating. Would you say your cat still has a healthy appetite? How are you giving them water? Litter box habits remain unchanged? Usually amount of energy/still has the motivation to do what it enjoys?
Water fountains encourage them to drink water a lot more. For food try giving canned food only (good quality brand, if kidney issues are suspected low protein specific kidney diet is best). If you must feed kibble try adding warm water to soften them and see if it encourages your cat to eat more. In the case of hard, dry kibble dental pain could also be a factor. You won't know unless you bring them in.

>>4360960
>>inb4 HURRR the caterpillars that that happened to have backsides resembling snakes survived predation more and bred more etc.
You're right in that this is an intellectually dishonest representation of how evolution works. If this were true, animals would evolve into overly complex but efficient creatures covered in wheels, etc.
One has to instead ask "what rudimentary structure, found commonly in nature and generally useful, was altered into this complex adaptation?"
For the caterpillar, this is eyespots. In nature, it's useful (keeps predators from targeting your head) and simple (just patches of color) to have false eyes.
>So how did "eyespots" become "snake caterpillar?"
This is where some conjecture must be employed. Bigger eyespots were probably favored, frightening predators away by masquerading as a larger animal instead of just hiding the head.
Once all of the caterpillars had frightening eyespots, natural selection favored the most frightening ones. Eyespots are combined with threat displays (many insects rear up), contrast coloration (many animals reveal a flash of color on the underbelly), and so on as the random mutations that make the caterpillar more frightening than his brothers are promoted.
But what about the fact that the caterpillar:
>doesnt even see and doesnt have a brain know it has to look like a snake?
It doesn't to know, and it never chose to look like a snake. Evolution never chose for the caterpillar to look like a snake. That it looks like a snake is a coincidence (influenced by the caterpillar's predators being terrified of snakes for other reasons).
This level of coincidence, in my mind, is the best evidence for God. "Impossibilities" arising from complex instruments (evolution) that only a superior being could orchestrate. Creationists who insist that God must have put all creation in place, unchanging, at the beginning? They belittle God's creativity, intelligence, and ability to plan for the future.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
E.V.O.: The Theory of Evolution is a Japanese elusive RPG for the NEC PC-9801 home computer. It was devolved by Almanic and published by Enix in 1990. The directer, Takashi Yoneda, is a science fiction author. He wanted to make a game that gave the player perspective on their place in the universe. This was the end result.

In E.V.O. you play as Gaia's chosen hero, an at first unremarkable creature that you are able to evolve over time into the peak life form. Your goal is to guide life in the right direction as the Devil tries to destroy it by tampering with evolution. The Devil has already tampered with the evolution of the surrounding planets, causing them to become lifeless. There is still some life on the moon, and how these aliens interacted with earth in the past and present is also a key plot point. Speculative evolution is even implemented in the later parts of the game.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
The actual combat system is passable, but the way you level up is interesting. There are no levels in the traditional sense, as you instead use your cumulative exp to spec into different stats individually. Once a stat is maxed out you are given the option to evolve. Enemies evolve at the same pace as you, so make sure to have a balanced character. Each new creature you evolve into has unique moves in combat and over world hazard resistances. It is also possible to evolve into an evolutionary dead end. Doing this is one of the ways to get a bad ending, which there are many of. These endings are just meant to be jokes, and you are not penalized for getting them. The manual even encourages you to find them all.

Overall I'd say that it's a "I watched a let's play" out of 10. The game is a very grind heavy for little game play substance. The combat is even more primitive than the original Dragon Quest. Its a shame really, because the plot and level system is something else. If it looked fun I'd be more eager to figure out how to emulate it, but as is the plot and themes are really what holds it up. It's a real shame then that the plot was butchered in the SNES reimagining E.V.O.: Search for Eden.
